Title: Trump and Powell are playing from the same strategy book: Morning Brief
Description:
Oops, something went wrong

This is The Takeaway from today's Morning Brief, which you can sign up to receive in your inbox every morning along with:

The chart of the day

What we're watching

What we're reading

Economic data releases and earnings

The stock market is used to the wait-and-see approach from the Fed. But now the president is riffing on that game plan too.

Their deliveries contrast sharply. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is explicit. We can wait and are in a position to do so. And as the outlook evolves and the tariff landscape takes shape, the central bank can take action with its powder dry.

Trump is opaque. When a sympathetic business journalist recently asked him to offer clarity to the market, he scoffed. The stock market's tanking? So what. Another day, another tariff. But the similarities between the two leaders come in the form of detachment from Wall Street panic and a longer-term view.

Trump isn't exactly known for his patience. But on the issue of levies, he's been both unyielding in thought and transactional in practice. Mexico and Canada received some reprieve, but Europe is under new threats. And the dizzying back-and-forth has created a conceptual traffic jam of economic paralysis that has reverberated through consumer sentiment.

Trump is daring heads of state to respond, Powell is waiting for Trump to make up his mind and data to change, and Wall Street is looking for the White House and the Fed to get off the fence.

If Trump's distinctive tariff policy is a time bomb, the explosion of them taking effect isn't the only dangerous part. It's the ticking, the randomness of the timer, the affliction caused by the endless anticipation. Businesses may dislike tariffs. But what they really hate is uncertainty.

Meanwhile, the Fed has to make sense of fluctuating pricing pressures.

On Thursday, new inflation data showed price increases slowed in February — but economists saw warning signs that the central bank may interpret as reasons to continue waiting.

Read more: From $5 eggs to insurance premiums, here's where prices are rising

"Thursday's inflation data is backward looking, and the real worry is the inflationary effects that may come from tariffs, which is a wildcard for markets and the Federal Reserve," said Paul Stanley, chief investment officer at Granite Bay Wealth Management. "It's too early to tell what tariffs mean for inflation because we don't know yet the extent of the tariffs or if the administration will end up reversing course and adopting a more dovish tariff policy."

But if tariff clarity is delayed indefinitely, it's hard to imagine rate cuts not sharing that itinerary.

The waiting game has other ripple effects. As this newsletter has discussed this week, Wall Street is struggling to calibrate the timing of Trump's pronouncements with their potential longer-term consequences. What triggers a stock market sell-off today might actually boost corporate profits later this year. That's a favorable way of viewing Trump's America First strategy.

“If the Fed makes monetary policy decisions based on policies enacted today, they could make substantial cuts to interest rates in 2025," said Bill Adams, chief economist for Comerica Bank. "On the other hand, if they assume that the overall fiscal stance will be more supportive of growth after factoring in decisions likely to be made later in the year, they may reduce rates only a little, if at all, in 2025."

Investors are used to the Fed's approach — and its straightforward dual mandate of stable prices and maximum employment. But they are still coming to grips with Trump's agenda. And as hard as it is to accept the sequencing of pain first and pleasure later, it's still not a guarantee.

So far, the only sure thing is discomfort for today and uncertainty for tomorrow.

Hamza Shaban is a reporter for Yahoo Finance covering markets and the economy. Follow Hamza on X @hshaban.

Title: Latest data shows inflation's fall to Fed's target 'continues to stall'
Description:
Oops, something went wrong

Two recent readings on inflation showed price increases decelerated in February — but within the details, economists see warning signs.

Thursday's report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics showed that its "core" Producer Price Index (PPI) — which tracks the price changes companies see and excludes food and energy — rose 3.4% from the year prior, down from the 3.6% seen in January. The day before, the bureau's Consumer Price Index (CPI) showed core prices rose 3.1% in February, the lowest yearly increase in core CPI since April 2021.

Read more: From $5 eggs to insurance premiums, here's where prices are rising

But the components from CPI and PPI that pass through to the Federal Reserve's preferred inflation measure — the core Personal Consumption Expenditures (PCE) index — indicate the closely followed inflation metric didn't fall in February.

Bank of America economists and several other Wall Street research teams now estimate that "core" PCE, which excludes food and energy, will show prices increased 2.7% in February, up from the 2.6% increase seen in January.

"This would indicate progress on inflation continues to stall and reinforces our call for the Fed to remain on hold," Bank of America US economist Stephen Juneau wrote in a note to clients.

The readings come amid investor fears that inflation may remain sticky while economic growth slows. In recent weeks, concerns over the latter have pushed markets to price in the possibility of a Fed interest cut in May. But after the two inflation readings, those bets have faded.

As of Thursday, markets were pricing in just a 30% chance the Fed cuts rates at its May meeting, down from a 52% chance seen a week ago, per the CME FedWatch Tool.

Economist Thomas Ryan also expects the two inflation readings to lead to an increase in the Fed's preferred inflation gauge for February.

"This is the opposite of the downward progress on inflation the Fed needs to see to justify easing policy further and reinforces our view that the window for cuts has already closed this year," the Capital Economics North America economist wrote.

Josh Schafer is a reporter for Yahoo Finance. Follow him on X @_joshschafer.

Title: Opinion: Nova Scotia leads the way on internal trade
Description:
Oops, something went wrong

The long-dreaded Trump tariffs have finally arrived. Canadians have been quick to rally against our increasingly unstable neighbour's economic threats, and at long last, Canadian governments have started to follow suit — finally prioritizing easier and cheaper buying and selling within our own borders. Old habits die hard, however, and progress continues to be unacceptably slow.

To their credit, governments are moving faster than ever, particularly on labour mobility, with key agreements set to be in place by June 1. A mutual recognition pilot program for trucking — though only a pilot program — is rolling out this spring, and the federal government has committed to cutting over half of its exceptions under 2017's Canadian Free Trade Agreement. More importantly, Nova Scotia has set a new benchmark with its bold Free Trade and Mobility within Canada Act, which adopts mutual recognition, the simple principle that if a product or worker is certified in any Canadian province, that's good enough for Nova Scotia. Now, provinces like Ontario, British Columbia and Alberta  are showing growing interest in following suit.

But “faster than ever” is a low bar, especially when the previous pace was barely a crawl, and Canada is now strapped to a ticking tariff time bomb. Barriers within Canada are a drag on trade equivalent to a 21 per cent internal tariff on goods and services, according to the International Monetary Fund. Even when international sourcing becomes more expensive, an internal tariff that high means buying domestically still may not feel like the better option. Commitments are great, but we need faster timelines for getting that 21 per cent tariff close to zero.

Some of the hoops Canadians are expected to jump through when moving goods and services across provincial borders can be ludicrous. A hairstylist from Manitoba can't cut hair in New Brunswick without being completely recertified. Construction sites in Ontario need different toilet seats than those in Alberta. Every province has its own requirements for individual coffee creamer packaging. Provincially inspected food can't move from Ottawa to Gatineau (a 10-minute drive) without being federally inspected. Because of inconsistent trucking regulations across the country, freight costs are an average of 8.3 per cent higher than they need to be. Canada has long championed sensible free trade agreements with the U.S., Europe, Asia and others but we have completely failed to apply the same principles of non-discrimination at home.

Nova Scotia's breakthrough was a game-changer, however. By introducing mutual recognition for goods, services and licences from reciprocating jurisdictions, Premier Tim Houston set a new standard for what's possible. Other provinces have since followed with incremental steps, joining agreements to facilitate labour mobility and direct-to-consumer alcohol shipments. But why stop there? What is everybody waiting for? Nova Scotia has shown the way forward.

With economic uncertainty looming, Canadian governments need to act now. At the Canadian Federation of Independent Business we have heard from countless small businesses that until now at least, it has been easier to work with American partners than with their neighbours in other parts of Canada. No wonder 88 per cent of small businesses surveyed say eliminating internal trade barriers needs to be a top priority. They say the maze of provincial regulations hinders their productivity and expansion. For consumers, that means less market competition, fewer job opportunities and higher prices. Yet, despite knowing that, until now governments have remained bogged down in painfully slow negotiations over minor technicalities, such as which high-visibility safety apparel all jurisdictions should adopt — on which negotiations are expected to drag on for nearly two more years!

It shouldn't have taken this long or required an elephant to come crashing against our door to make a free internal market a top priority. But now we need to seize the moment. Canadians have been quick to raise their elbows, show unity and rally behind Canadian businesses. Now, it's time for governments to match that urgency by breaking down the barriers that have been blocking internal trade.

Red tape is the silent killer of businesses

Do we fight Trump to our last sacred cow?

Nova Scotia has shown the way. Which premier will step up next? Some seem ready to follow suit, but if Canadian leaders are as committed as they claim, the answer should be: all of them. No business should find it easier to trade abroad than at home. It's time to get this done, once and for all.

SeoRhin Yoo is senior policy analyst for interprovincial affairs at the Canadian Federation of Independent Business.

Bookmark our website and support our journalism: Don't miss the business news you need to know — add financialpost.com to your bookmarks and sign up for our newsletters here.
